mainmatter.p: The Stone adjunction is the one formed by the open set functor \mathcal{O} : \mathbf{Top} \to \mathbf{Frm} and the point functor \mathsf{Pt} : \mathbf{Frm} \to \mathbf{Top}.
Adapted by Ayberk Tosun from the handbook chapter of Abramsky and Jung.
Given a topological space X, let \mathcal{O} ( X ) denote its class of opens.

As \mathcal{O} ( X ) is a frame, we can view this as a mapping \mathcal{O} : \mathbf{Top} \to \mathbf{Frm}, which we can then extend to a contravariant functor:
let f : X \to Y be a continuous map of topological spaces,
\mathcal{O} (f) should then be mapping from the frame \mathcal{O} ( Y ) to \mathcal{O} ( X ),
given some U \in \mathcal{O} ( Y ), \mathcal{O} (f)(U) := f^{-1}(U) which is in \mathcal{O} ( X ) precisely by the continuity of f.
Let L be a frame. A point of L is a completely prime filter of the lattice L.
The collection of all points of a frame L is denoted \mathsf{pt} ( L ).
This collection of all points can be topologised by equipping it with a class of opens as follows.

Let U \subseteq \mathsf{pt} ( L ) be a set of points of L. The set U is taken as open if it satisfies: \exists x \in L. \ \forall F \in U. \ x \in F. In other words, there is some "open" x \in L which is an open neighbourhood of every "point" F \in U.

This can be viewed as a mapping \mathsf{pt} : \mathbf{Frm} \to \mathbf{Top}, which is then extended to a contravariant functor \mathbf{Frm} ^{ \mathsf{op} } \to \mathbf{Top}. Let h : M \to L be a frame homomorphism. The functor \mathsf{pt} should then give a continuous map \mathsf{pt} (h) : \mathsf{pt} ( L ) \to \mathsf{pt} ( M ) which is defined as \mathsf{pt} (h)(F) := h^{-1}(F).
